reviewText:
Creepypasta Attempt #1:

I got on Steam and saw this game on the first of April and bought it because I thought it was an April Fool’s joke.

Scratch that.

Creepypasta Attempt #2:

I got on Steam and saw this game on the first of April and bought it because I’m an idiot.

No, no, no.

Creepypasta Attempt #3:

I got on Steam and saw that I had been gifted a game. I didn’t recognize who sent it and the message along with it went as so:

“Dear Withering Soul,

You are lost in your pitiful life. Test your limits.”

I downloaded it with hesitant fingers clenching the mouse with building tension. The game started and I was thrust into a dark forest. I clicked a birdhouse, then a doll, then A SPOOKY .JPG CAME OUT! I was now by a crying woman. I clicked a swing set, then the woman, then A SPOOKY .JPG CAME OUT! Later I went to Hell for some reason and there were three hanging, farting dead people and A SPOOKY .JPG CAME OUT!

This was Real Horror Stories Ultimate Edition. I hated this game. I hated it. I hate, hate, hated it. I don’t hate it because it scared me, but simply because it bored me. The only thing scary is that the creator is getting money for this bull. You loosely swing between random places and have things pop out at you. What people forget is there is a difference between being horrified and being startled. This game startles you for brief seconds. Which can be okay, but I didn’t get startled at all. This game TRIES to startle you for brief seconds. The only problem is that you’ll be bored to tears between the “scares,” so you just don’t get scared. My shoulders jumped once and I think it was because a fly landed on my arm.

I can’t recommend this unless you saved up money from selling cards and you don’t feel like buying DLC. Don’t tell all your friends not to buy this because they’ll go out and do it anyway. Just ignore the game and forget about it. That is the worst thing you can do about terrible horror games: feel nothing and see them as irrelevant.

I was born in Bosnia.  My parents were killed in the wars, and I was left an orphan.  I was adopted by an old turnip farmer, and he raised me as his own.  I thought that my life was going to be ruled by poverty, but one day, fortune struck.  An old laptop fell off the back of a truck. and it was mostly unharmed.  I knew what I was destined to do:  make Let's Plays of Minecraft and Spooky Games.  I started squatting in an abandoned house above a Starbucks, stealing internet from them and luckily, the old house still had power.

I had hit a brick wall, though.  I didn't have any money, and I only had food and water from the farm, and from discarded pastries and half-caf diet iced caramel frothaccinos with cigarrette butts in them that people so carelessly left on the tables as they left the store, or went to the bathroom.

After months of despair, today, yes today ladies and gentlemen, was the day I finally found a game I could afford.  For only nineteen cents, this game would launch my Let's Play career, and I would make millions of Youtube dollars.

I fished a quarter out of a wishing well and ran as fast as I could to the farm.  I asked my adopted father if I could have the money from his Mastercard if I gave him the same amount in cold, hard cash, and when he said no, I just took his credit card and bought it anyway.  Don't worry, I put both the card and the quarter back in his wallet soon after.

Ladies and gentlemen, today is the day I start my Let's Play career, and when the money I get from videos from this game starts rolling in, I'll finally be able to buy Minecraft and start making millions.

Ladies and gentlemen...you're looking at the next PewDiePie.

Serious review below (because joke reviews are not useful, but a waste of time):

This is a supposedly enhanced version of a free web game, with more puzzles, better graphics than the original version and a clue system, that helps you if you are stuck for a very long time in one the game's levels. Want to demo the game on your browser? Try using google and you'll find it. The idea behind it is nice, but it is badly executed. Lack of clues to solve puzzles, one annoying puzzle that forces you to have great mouse control with lots of trial and error, a puzzle that requires you to memorize a word from a large text, etc.

The game's sounds are good, but become very repetitive if you take too long to finish a room. There are some very weird and disgusting scenarios that fit the game well. The jump scares can frighten some people, but they are overused and predictable, with a B-horror, funny effect.

I bought this because of the huge discount (75%) and because the game gives you cards, so I ended up paying a negligible price for the game after selling the 3 cards it gave me.

Unless you want this game's cards, stick to the free version, which never got some annoying endgame puzzles.

reviewText:
So seriously, I have not been spooked more in all of my life as I know it, no joke. It was REALLY scary. This game has been a very enjoyable thrill-vill ride of chaos, suspension, and candle-lighting. None in all my gaming career have I ever been faced with such challenging and promising puzzles. I think I can sleep easy now knowing that games like this exist purely to give us that special butterfly feeling in our tummys.  Truly a standard the gaming industry should partake in. Why would you want to ever do micro-transactions like in Dead Space 3, when instead you can enjoy a good old-fashioned spooky transaction. Countries should learn a thing or two about this kind new currency that is currently only available in the pure spook of Real Horror Stories.™

This is a story about a man who is haunted by the visions of his dead daughter, boy, mother, and wife. It is revealed in the later-plot that they were killed by asphyixation, and dumped in the well by the protagonist. In response to the protagonist's evil doings, the massacred family strike a deal with the spirits of the forest, and, using their combined power, created a mystical labyrinth to test the protagonist. (Who we learn name's is Belial.) The spirits and the family design the rough, ardous challenges of tracing your cursor (Which we later learn is a satan conjuring wand.) through a difficult, poor-hitboxed maze made on purpose to test the protagonist's frustration of the hatred for his family. When the story finally comes to a climax, you must finish what you started by defeating Pudge, (From Dota 2) who frequently appears on your screen, and returning your wife to her watery grave. Then, you are left with a choice. The guru of stone is finally able to reach you, and presents you with both his hands.

This final epic climax demonstrates the deep moral choices of the protagonist. He must chose between his left hand, (the will of the few, since most people use their mouse (Satan Conjuring Wand) with their right hand.) and the right hand. (the will of the Protagonist, since most players would use their mouse (Satan Conjuring Wand) with their right hand.) If the Protagonist choses the left hand, he is released from his prison, and his family and the spirits are sealed in the well. If he choses the right, he choses his own selfish desires, and is doomed to endless fire and brimstone.

Endless Replay Value
10/10

And things do make you jump (as much because they just appear). But the link between chapters is so tenuous and light that there is no story or journey at all, merely a collection of images. This one alas gets 9/10 for nice effect but 4/10 for story, thus 8/10 overall. I recommend to point-and-click fans if you can get it for cheap, it's quite quick to complete, an hour or two. It passes the time nicely enough and enjoy (somewhat) a genre that we don't see too often.

reviewText:
This game calls itself Real Horror Stories.

And I believe it. In real life, I find myself poking things until they make a *slightly* different noise than before, and I get a jump-scare, usually in the form of police. Yep, that's Biggles' good ol' day-to-day.

The problem, you could say then, is that this game is TOO real. I don't want to be reminded of that time I played Simon Says to unlock a spooky door, or that time I hung out with a crucified Pope. Those were rough days!

Oh, or how about that time I could only progress by lighting an arbitrary pattern of candles? That Slayer concert didn't go well at ALL.

You see, this game, much like life, is a sequence of poorly-photoshopped flitered .png files. Occasionally, by which I mean literally twice, it does present a challenge with some logic and reasoning that you can sorta see if you squint hard enough and tilt your head and hold your breath nearly long enough to pass out. Too often though, the solution is simply to poke a random object MORE TIMES. While this happens more often in life than you'd think (ask your parents, kids), it's not exactly fun.

So, let's move onto word #2 of the title.

reviewText:
There are a few decent wallpaper worthy backgrounds in this point & click adventure.
If you're looking for something scary and chilling, you might get it with this game.

There are several ghostly encounters for the player while traveling through some disturbing scenery
however to be brutally honest, You play as someone who is invincible and seem to be able to withstand any 'attacks' they recieve. Nothing can kill you and for some reason you carry on forward.

The forumla eventually becomes over done quickly and you easily ready yourself for any jump scare because you'll learn the method from repetiton of gameplay.

There is no story, So you wont know who you are, where you are going or why you have chosen to walk through this except for a few newspaper articles at the start of the game. which still dont reveal much or connect to scenes later on.

The game can be finished within an hour, probably less and some scenes you can work out the puzzles within seconds or some puzzles are so cryptic that you'll be googling an answer ASAP. One puzzle even relies on a clue left in a previous scene that you cannot turn back and obtain.

This game may be scary to some but it wont bother the most experinced of horror game veterans, it might scare off little children but I think its probably more suited for your grandmother who is currently dealing with a mid life crisis thing and wants to do something different with their life before they kick the bucket. Here's something you can give them to get them started.

reviewText:
My friends and I have a game during Steam sales in which we buy each other terrible games and then we have to stream as we play them. Due to that, I now own this gem.

Let me preface this review by saying I love horror films. I love scary stories. The Final Girl is my spirit animal. All this being said, I have a low tolerance for scares. During particularly terrifying films, I will sit, feet up in my chair, knees under my chin, hands plastered to my face as I watch between my fingers like a frightened five year old. But I will suffer through when it's worth it.

Real Horror Stories Ultimate Edition is not worth it. It is terrible. It is awful. As a point-and-click adventure there are no real puzzles or mystery, just following the cues on-screen to get to the next part.

And on top of all of this, the game relies on jumpscares. The atmosphere is shoddily built, with shadowy figures flickering the background or glowing eyes in the depths of a cave, and as you play you know when the scary moment is going to happen as it is based on a predictable pacing. When you jump in your chair, it is more from a release of your own tension and your imagination of what might be coming than from the game actually being scary. Because anyone's imagination is freakier than what this game can come up with.

Though my friends were disappointed, I quit playing this game after just a half hour because it wasn't worth it. I quit because I knew that I would be jumping throughout this game, but hating myself for it. If I wanted that, I would go back and grit my teeth and play through Dead Space. (One day, Dead Space!) But this game is something that, if you're like me, you're just going to be a bit freaked out and irritated at yourself for being suckered into the lame scares. Or, if you're someone with a higher tolerance for atmosphere and jumpscares, you're just going to be unhappy that you wasted any money at all on a Flash game that is offered for free online[www.gameshed.com].

When I was seven my pet labrador, Katie, took a large, wretched dump in the living room. It was during dinner time, and while there was little to no flatulence, the smell which was at first indistinguishable from mother's brussel sprout and spinach cassarole, gained flavor and bouquet as my parents and I began gagging. She had brought a few bird carcasses inside after the neighbor's cat was done playing with them the night before, so I can only assume that this was the culprit. My parents were kind enough to ignore this indecorum, as Katie had spent several minutes trying to clean the mess with her tongue before we discovered her, but this didn't change the combination lemonade/brownie cake in the carpet, nor the dribble trail following it from the doggie door. I'd like to say that we all bonded over the thorough cleaning that ensued, but father placed a cinder block in front of Katie's door and she spent the remainder of the week outside. My mother tried her best to make the living room appealing to us all again, but we just moved the television into the dining room doorway and tried not to think about what Febreeze-covered ♥♥♥♥ smelled like.

Is this game Katie, Katie's wretched dump, mother's cassarole, or Febreeze-covered ♥♥♥♥?

Whatever you decide, yes.

reviewText:
For reals?!  What the sh*t is going on in this game?? Yeah, I know, it’s supposed to be based on urban legends and the like, but if that’s the case then the developers must have made up some of their own because virtually nothing in the game seems to be based even remotely on actual events/folktales.  Ask yourself:  When did some Pope-looking dude ever get struck by lightning in a place that looks like the cover to a classic rock album while a horned-Yeti-looking-thing goes gallivanting around?  That’s right, never!!

I guess stuff like that was added to make the game more appealing to horror fans; to make it scarier (if that can even be said in this context because that’s the one thing this game most certainly is not).

Regardless, nothing makes sense in this game and the point-and-click mechanic, especially when it comes to how you solve most of the puzzles, was so poorly conceived and implemented that you’ll likely be pointing and clicking as quickly as possible to delete all local content while you still have some sanity left.  At that point, alas, no one can give you back the time you spent playing the game….*sigh*….

I got this when it was less than $1 – I now realize in retrospect that that simply wasn’t cheap enough but at least it now has trading cards so you can kinda recoup the anguish and mental scarring this game causes (the cards are truly the only plus side to this game).

Consider yourself forewarned!

For reals?!  What the sh*t is going on in this game?? Yeah, I know, it’s supposed to be based on urban legends and the like, but if that’s the case then the developers must have made up some of their own because virtually nothing in the game seems to be based even remotely on actual events/folktales. I guess stuff like that was added to make the game more appealing to horror fans; to make it scarier (if that can even be said in this context because that’s the one thing this game most certainly is not).

At that point, alas, no one can give you back the time you spent playing the game….*sigh*….

I got this when it was less than $1 – I now realize in retrospect that that simply wasn’t cheap enough but at least it now has trading cards so you can kinda recoup the anguish and mental scarring this game causes (the cards are truly the only plus side to this game).

Consider yourself forewarned!

My parents were kind enough to ignore this indecorum, as Katie had spent several minutes trying to clean the mess with her tongue before we discovered her, but this didn't change the combination lemonade/brownie cake in the carpet, nor the dribble trail following it from the doggie door. I'd like to say that we all bonded over the thorough cleaning that ensued, but father placed a cinder block in front of Katie's door and she spent the remainder of the week outside. Is this game Katie, Katie's wretched dump, mother's cassarole, or Febreeze-covered ♥♥♥♥?

reviewText:
I both do and do not recommend this game.

Cheap scares (things popping up in front of the screen mostly.) Other than that, atmosphere isn't that scary.

The controls don't make a huge amount of sense, there doesn't seem to be a logical progression for figuring out the puzzles. You, basically, just click around until you get lucky and something happens. A lot of times, you have to click everything 3-4 times before it even triggers anything which makes it feel like you aren't accomplishing anything on purpose.

I got it for $0.29 and am a little bored. I did jump once or twice, so if you absolutely love horror stories I would recommend it if you can get it on a great sale. But don't expect much.
